sen.j: 讃岐神社（さぬきじんじゃ）は、奈良県北葛城郡広陵町にある神社である。
sen.e: Sanuki-jinja is located at Koryocho, Kitakatsuragigun in Nara Prefecture.
Sanuki-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine is located in Koryocho, Kitakatsuragigun, Nara Prefecture.
Sanuki-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Koryo-cho, Kitakatsuragi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 文法修正しました。住所表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は村社。
sen.e: Shikinaisha Shrine listed in the Engishiki and Sonsha Shrine (a villge shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
It is a shikinaisha (listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) and was classified as a sonsha (village shrine) under the old shrine ranking system.
It is a shikinaisha (listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) and was classified as a sonsha (village shrine) under the old shrine ranking system.
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined deities
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 現在は、国魂・若宇加能売命・大物主を祀るとしている。
sen.e: At present, it is said that the shrine enshrines Kunitama,,Wakaukanome-no-Mikoto and Omononushi.
At present, it is said that the shrine enshrines Kunitama,,Wakaukanome-no-Mikoto and Omononushi.
At present, it is said that the shrine enshrines Kunitama, Wakaukanome-no-Mikoto and Omononushi.

sen.j: 『日本三代実録』元慶7年（883年）12月2日条には「散吉大建命・散吉伊能城神に神階従五位下を授ける」という記述があり、当社の神のこととみられる。
sen.e: "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku (a history book written in the Heian Period)" describes, in the article of December 2 in 883, that Sanukiotakeru-no-Mikoto and Sanukiinoki-no-kami are conferred the divine rank of the Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, which suggests they are the deities of the shrine.

"Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (a history book written in the Heian Period) describes in the article of December 2 in 883 that Sanukiotakeru-no-Mikoto and Sanukiinoki-no-kami were conferred the divine rank of the Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, which suggests they are the deities of the shrine.

"Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (a history book written in the Heian period) describes in the article of December 2 in 883 that Sanukiotakeru-no-Mikoto and Sanukiinoki-no-kami were conferred the divine rank of the Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, which suggests they are the deities of the shrine.
History
History
History

sen.j: 鎮座地名の「三吉」は「みつよし」と読むが、かつては「散吉」と書いて「さぬき」と読んでいた。
sen.e: The name of the enshrined place"三吉" is pronounced as 'Mitsuyoshi' but formerly it was written as "散吉"and pronounced as 'Sanuki'.
The area in which the shrine is located (三吉) is pronounced as 'Mitsuyoshi' but was formerly written '散吉'and pronounced as 'Sanuki'.
The area in which the shrine is located (三吉) is pronounced as 'Mitsuyoshi' but was formerly written '散吉' and pronounced as 'Sanuki.'
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 一帯は讃岐国の忌部氏が移り住んだ地で、讃岐の故郷の神を勧請し創建したものとみられる。
sen.e: The Inbe clan moved to the area from their birthplace in Sanuki Province and founded the shrine transferring a divided tutelary deity to a new location.
The Inbe clan moved to the area from their birthplace in Sanuki Province and founded the shrine, transferring a divided tutelary deity to the new location.
The Inbe clan moved to the area from their birthplace in Sanuki Province and founded the shrine, transferring a divided tutelary deity to the new location.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では「大和国広瀬郡 讃岐神社」と記載され、小社に列格している。
sen.e: The shrine is listed as 'Sanuki-jinja Shrine, Hirose District, Yamato Province' and ranked as shosha (small shrine) in the Engishiki law.
The shrine is listed as 'Sanuki-jinja Shrine, Hirose District, Yamato Province' and ranked as shosha (small shrine) in the Engishiki law.
The shrine is listed as 'Sanuki-jinja Shrine, Hirose District, Yamato Province' and ranked as shosha (small shrine) in the Engishiki law.

sen.j: 広瀬川合（現 廣瀬大社）の若宇加乃売命を勧請したことにより、江戸時代までは「広瀬大明神」「南川合明神」と称していた。
sen.e: The shrine was known as 'Hirose Daimyojin God' or 'Minami Kawai Myojin God' until the Edo period because of the transfer of the divided deity Wakaukanome-no-Mikoto from Hirose Kawai (the present Hirose Taisha Shrine) to the shrine.

The shrine was known as 'Hirose Daimyojin' or 'Minami Kawai Myojin' until the Edo period because of the transfer of the divided deity Wakaukanome-no-Mikoto from Hirose Kawai (the present Hirose Taisha Shrine) to the shrine.

The shrine was known as 'Hirose Daimyojin' or 'Minami Kawai Myojin' until the Edo period because of the transfer of the divided deity Wakaukanome-no-Mikoto from Hirose Kawai (the present Hirose Taisha Shrine) to the shrine.

sen.j: 慶長19年（1611年）正月に火災があり、現在の本殿はそのときに再建されたものである。
sen.e: A fire broke out in January, 1611 and the existing main hall was rebuilt after the fire.
A fire broke out in January, 1611 and the existing main hall was rebuilt after the fire.
A fire broke out in January 1611 and the existing main hall was rebuilt after the fire.
Relevance to Taketori Monogatari (The tale of Bamboo Cutter)
Relevance to Taketori Monogatari (The tale of Bamboo Cutter)
Relevance to Taketori Monogatari (The tale of Bamboo Cutter)

sen.j: 竹取物語に登場する「竹取の翁」が名を「讃岐造（さぬきのみやつこ）」ということから、これが大和国広瀬郡散吉郷のことであるとして、「竹取物語ゆかりの神社」を称している。
sen.e: The shrine calls itself 'a shrine in connection with Taketori Monogatari' since 'Taketori no Okina',a character in the story, is also known as 'Sanuki-no-Miyatsuko' that implies that the setting of the story is Sanuki-go, Hirose district, Yamato Province.

The shrine claims to have a connection to Taketori Monogatari because 'Taketori no Okina,' a character in the story, is also known as 'Sanuki-no-Miyatsuko,' implying that the setting of the story is Sanuki-go, Hirose district, Yamato Province.

The shrine claims to have a connection to Taketori Monogatari because 'Taketori no Okina,' a character in the story, is also known as 'Sanuki-no-Miyatsuko,' implying that the setting of the story is Sanuki-go, Hirose district, Yamato Province.
